reviews.review_msg: One of the most caring professors at SFU. He's very knowledgeable about international affairs. I've taken 3 courses with him and always enjoyed informative lectures and got rewarded for my participation in class. He seemed to struggle with assignment guideline in this course, perhaps bcz he tried to incorporate too many suggestions from students

Brutal lectures. He overloads students with WAY more examples than needed, way past the point when everyone understands the concept. Not good with technology, wastes a lot of time trying to get videos to load. Assignment guidelines unclear and disorganized.

Very dissapointed in a professor who uses a 3rd-year lecture as her personal soap-box.  If you don't agree with her extreme-left ideologies and feminist rhetoric then don't bother. Her shock value goes beyond keeping students interested and crosses into the realm of distraction.  Good-luck focusing on the actual course content!

Worst class i've ever taken.  Silva obviously hated our class, and she did not make any point of trying to hide it.  She was not approachable, or friendly, or willing to help.  She was annoyed with the amount of emails she received, and she made you feel stupid if you didn't agree with her. Bah!

interesting and thought provoking lectures...guys might not like it...she's an obvious feminist and her lectures do demonstate this...but its about time for a strong opinionated female professor to come around...

very biased. does not give room for creativity or self-expression. how can anyone like this teach? total propaganda and brainwashing. i don't think there is a need to be referring to homosexuality during evey lecture.

lecture topics are interesting but what is really annoying and frustrating is how she presents the material in class, her personal biasness makes the stuff she talks about less appealing... Avoid her if you don't want lectures in the feminist perspective!
she's very knowledgeable, but like what the person before me posted, sort of like her way or the highway.
I *so* regret taking this class! It is so dry & boring and Silva's personal biasness gets in the way. It's her opinion or the highway.
Hot as hell. I have no idea what this class was about.

has bad breathe which is likely because he is genetically recessive. stuffy and overly philosophical for a course on everyday life. I must admit though that he really is a complete sex bomb. God help us if he becomes a prof.
Will miss his grandiosity
Is purely interested in philosophy.

Scott was by far one of the worst TA's I have ever had. Given that this class title is communication in everday life, Scott seems to overlook that and focuses more on making life and class impossible to complete. He is extremely arrogant and very difficult to approach. Personally I have never met a worse TA. Communication becomes flawed bc of him.

I've had tough TAs but it was always in "tough love." This guy goes out of his way to make life difficult (see below comments.) Half my tutorial switched or dropped. If you decide to tough it out and Scot goes too far, email the professor. It was only then that Scot stopped kicking people out and the proposal was changed back to 2 pages.

Horrible person. Kicked people out the first class for being even 2 min. late. Rude, mean, unreachable expectations. Having him as a teacher is a big regret.  I hope karma makes him suffer the way we have to suffer with him. I don't know how I will be able to get through this class.  Horrible person.

The first rating is totally bogus. Scott is mean, aggressive, uses unprofessional language, lies about assignment expectations (says a proposal is 8-10 pages when it's really only 2), kicks people out of class if they show up 5 min. late, and constantly interrupts the tutorial to chastise the late student. Hard marker, readings mandatory, scary guy
No Comments

He is a great TA who helps his students and stuff. Super easy going guy, really friendly, and nice. He totally grades easy, so if your into an easy A TAKE HIS CLASS. I like, did no readings a nd got an A+. LOVE HIM!
This TA actually cares. What a shock! Discussions get kind of off topic sometimes and also a hard marker!
good TA...knowledgable and interesting....but not very approachable or friendly

The lectures for this course is super fun but when you have to sit down and write your own paper, most likely, you'll be stuck and become irritated. Although Gary is delighted prof, his TA was unhelpful and unclear..think before you take this course!!!!
A very interesting lecturer, with soem lectures actually being applicable to everyday life. Amazing stuff.
GREAT GUY!!  Very smart, entertaining and challenging...

An excellent teacher who's always willing to help the students out.  ** If you get the chance to take a class with him, DO NOT pass it up! **  He's super intelligent and a genuinely good guy.  Great lectures - lots of humor and insight.
Great Prof., Great elaboration.
articulate, funny, sincere

She is a caring professor but extremely authoritative. She loses her mind if you even glance at your phone in class and is very judgy with people who might be struggling in her class. Not supper accommodating, judgemental, authoritative, controlling, and rude.
What an amazing instructor. This here is a professor who cares about his students.
Neiman has an interesting background and we're lucky to have him teaching us!

He's such an amazing guy that I would chill with him for fun. Regardless of what grade you get, this is the most genuinely interesting class I've taken at SFU. I'd recommend it for anyone interested in language, dialogue & the human experience.
good
An amazing prof. His lectures were fun and very interesting. This course is definitely worth taking.

One of the most intelligent and genuine profs in CMNS, if you are lucky enough to have him. Terry has had my full attention in every one of our 9AM lectures, and every time, I am compelled to fill my notebook with his words. If you are someone who has a brain and cares for social discourse, you will find this class very intellectually stimulating.

At first I thought I hated Terry because of his dislike of big words. (Seriously, this is an UD CMNS course...) But it turns out I've loved this class. He's a great lecturer & really wants people to learn. You MUST do the readings & keep up with the course. Exams are actually based on learning & understanding, not rote memorisation-what a concept!!

I really like Terry, he is funny and engaging, he does his best to get class participation and he does lots of activities to break the long class up. He is a bit confusing in that it is not always easy to know how what we are talking about relates to the course but if you ask questions he is happy to clarify. He's a cool guy. Course is very different from what I expected, but Terry is a smart guy.

Terry comes off as a great guy. However, his lectures tend to be quite dry most of the time and the readings even drier. For my semester he decided to take attendance in lecture (wasn't a seminar), which really put me off. The class itself is interesting, but the way he presents the material could use a face-lift.
Really intelligent. He is helpful, and makes an effort to make the class interesting and interactive.
I wish someone else would teach the course :(
Hands down one of the most intelligent profs I have ever come across. This guy just knows stuff about everything and made lectures very enjoyable.

Terry is a wonderful prof and an excellent T/A. He is passionate about what he is teaching and is helpful when students ask questions. This course definitely pushes you to come up with your own ideas and work a little more independently. Topics are not just handed to you on a silver platter. Welcome to upper division courses.

Terry is an awesome. Genuinely nice lecturer and seems to really care in  helping others learn. can't help the fact that the course material is a bit dry overall but it is a 3rd year course. Also, marking is fair but a bit difficult to attain 'excellent' marks.

I'm surprised at all the bad comments - it's not the most exciting class I've ever taken, that's for sure, but Terry is a nice guy and not a hard marker - good sense of humor too. Rambles a bit in lecture, but if you pay attention and do most of the readings, you're set. Seriously, this class is NOT as difficult as people are making it out to be!!

Terry was one of the best professors I've had at SFU. Some of the other comments on this thread are completely ridiculous; I didn't see half of those things in class! Terry is very fair and has a unique teaching and marking style which I thought was very helpful. He is very nice, clearly interested in the course content, and happy to offer help!

Neiman is the worst professor I have encountered so far at SFU. He teaches first year concepts in his 3rd year class, is biased and unhelpful. his textbook is useless, his examples are irrelevant, and his overall attitude towards students is poor. i wish i hadn't taken his class.
Don't understand what is trying to get at many of the times...make me have a bad impression of dialogue courses in CMNS. He can be very vague.
Avoid at all cost.The most biased prof I have ever come across. He has a huge ego and loves to hear his own voice.

Neiman is the worst prof anyone could ever have. He loves to hear himself talk while he ignores the concerns of the students. he is not very supportive or attentive during his office hours. kinda makes you feel like you are wasting his time. his class makes no sense and neiman seems to enjoy the fact that his students are all confused.

Terry is an extremely smart guy.  This class is definately not what I thought it would be- "communication in everyday life"... the fairly complex ideas you learn seem like they couldn't be further from everyday life, but they end up making sense.
